clues.answer: This standard, released in parallel with 802.11b, introduced OFDM but operated in the 5 GHz band, limiting its initial adoption.
clues.question: 802.11a

clues.answer: This popular early standard used the 2.4 GHz band and DSSS, offering a nominal data rate of 11 Mbps.
clues.question: 802.11b

clues.answer: Offering a straightforward upgrade from 802.11b, this standard brought the faster OFDM technology to the 2.4 GHz band for a 54 Mbps data rate.
clues.question: 802.11g

clues.answer: Now known as Wi-Fi 4, this standard introduced MIMO technology and could operate in both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands.
clues.question: 802.11n

clues.answer: Also known as Wi-Fi 5, this standard was designed to work only in the 5 GHz band and introduced wider channel bonding up to 160 MHz.
clues.question: 802.11ac

clues.answer: The media access method used by Wi-Fi to avoid collisions, rather than just detecting them like Ethernet.
clues.question: CSMA/CA (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance)

clues.answer: A device that acts as the center of a logical star topology in a wireless LAN, mediating connections for client devices.
clues.question: Access Point (AP)

clues.answer: Of the two common Wi-Fi frequency bands, this one is better at penetrating solid surfaces and offers longer range.
clues.question: 2.4 GHz

clues.answer: The technology that uses multiple antennas for transmitting and receiving to increase bandwidth and signal reliability.
clues.question: MIMO (Multiple Input Multiple Output)

clues.answer: This technique combines two adjacent 20 MHz channels into a single, wider 40 MHz channel to increase bandwidth.
clues.question: Channel Bonding

clues.answer: The common name for the 802.11ax standard, which introduced technologies like OFDMA.
clues.question: Wi-Fi 6

clues.answer: A key feature of Wi-Fi 6, this modulation scheme allows a channel to be subdivided into smaller resource units for parallel communication with multiple devices.
clues.question: OFDMA (Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiple Access)

clues.answer: This technology, enhanced in Wi-Fi 5 and 6, allows an AP to communicate with multiple stations simultaneously using different spatial streams.
clues.question: MU-MIMO (Multiuser MIMO)

clues.answer: Wi-Fi 6 was the first standard to officially specify the use of this new, less congested frequency band to achieve the highest data rates.
clues.question: 6 GHz

clues.answer: A feature that allows an access point to encourage clients to connect to the less crowded 5 GHz or 6 GHz bands instead of 2.4 GHz.
clues.question: Band Steering

clues.answer: The common name for a wireless network, which can be up to 32 characters long.
clues.question: SSID (Service Set Identifier)

clues.answer: The arrangement of a single access point and the client stations it serves.
clues.question: BSS (Basic Service Set)

clues.answer: The MAC address of an access point's radio that serves as the unique identifier for a Basic Service Set.
clues.question: BSSID (Basic Service Set Identifier)

clues.answer: A group of multiple access points connected to the same wired network, all sharing the same network name to allow for roaming.
clues.question: ESS (Extended Service Set)

clues.answer: The name of the management frame broadcast by an AP to advertise its presence, SSID, and other capabilities.
clues.question: Beacon Frame

clues.answer: An unauthorized access point connected to a network, creating a potential security backdoor.
clues.question: Rogue AP

clues.answer: A rogue AP that impersonates a legitimate AP by spoofing its SSID to trick users into connecting.
clues.question: Evil Twin

clues.answer: An attack that sends spoofed management frames to force a client or all clients to disconnect from the AP.
clues.question: Deauthentication Attack

clues.answer: A webpage that appears after a user connects to a public Wi-Fi network, requiring them to agree to terms or log in.
clues.question: Captive Portal

clues.answer: A system that monitors the airwaves to detect unauthorized access points and other wireless threats.
clues.question: WIDS (Wireless Intrusion Detection System)
